docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show. Museums FREDERICK J. BROWN, ''Portraits in Jazz, Blues and Other Icons,'' Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500 (through June 29). This three-decade, 30-piece retrospective profiles a painter who has restlessly explored Modernist abstraction, Neo-Expressionist narrative and portraiture. His big, luxuriantly congested, storytelling pictures from the 1980's are the most visually rich and imaginatively expansive. His portraits of great jazz and blues musicians are, at their best, theatrically energetic. But a big double portrait of Willem de Kooning steals the show. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $7; $3, students and 62+ (Ken Johnson).

docs.lead_paragraph: Directed by Thaddeus O'Sullivan R, 96 minutes All the high-toned accouterments that signify the ''Masterpiece Theater'' style of wistful Anglophilia embellish ''The Heart of Me,'' an undercooked romantic drama set largely in London during the 1930's and 40's. If the elegant home furnishings, smart literary references, soft-focus cinematography and plodding semiclassical score (by Nicholas Hooper) evoke Merchant-Ivory, the end product suggests tepid, bottom-drawer Merchant-Ivory in which the emotions rarely catch fire.
docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews movie The Heart of Me, directed by Thaddeus O'Sullivan; Helena Bonham Carter and Paul Bettany star (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who are pregnant with boys take in 10 percent more calories than those carrying girls, researchers have found. ''Boy babies tend to be about 100 grams heavier on average than girl babies, and it's never been explained as to why that might be,'' said the lead author of the study, Dr. Rulla M. Tamimi of the Harvard School of Public Health. One hundred grams is 3.5 ounces.
docs.abstract: Dr Rulla M Tamimi, Harvard School of Public Health researcher, reports findings in BMJ medical journal that show pregnant women carrying male babies consume average of 10% more calories during pregnancy; findings could explain reason why boy babies generally weigh more than girl babies at birth; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Elephant Hybrids Q. Can Asian and African elephants mate successfully? A. Such a mating would never occur in the wild, because of the two species' different ranges, and it is strongly opposed for several reasons by Mike Keel, the species survival plan coordinator for elephants of the American Zoo and Aquarium Association.
docs.abstract: Q & A column discusses whether Asian and African elephants could sucessfully mate; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on May 29 about obstetricians who have left their practices because of the cost of malpractice insurance included an erroneous comparison from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. In many states, only neurosurgeons -- not neurologists as well -- pay higher premiums than obstetricians. The article also misstated the location of Everett, Wash., where one expectant mother found a doctor after her obstetrician in Mount Vernon, Wash., stopped delivering babies. It is south of Mount Vernon, not north.
docs.abstract: Correction of May 29 article about obstetricians who have left their practices because of cost of malpractice insurance regarding cost comparison of insurance for other specialties
